posts.name: Ephraim C.
posts.cooked: The user is attempting to simulate robot code due to limited access to the actual robot during nearly summer months. They aim to test limit switches within the simulateJava environment but are unsure how to trigger them effectively. To address this, they should explore the simulateJava code for any built-in functionalities or events related to limit switches. Checking documentation or seeking assistance from community forums may offer workarounds or alternative solutions. If necessary, designing a custom solution within the simulation framework could enable them to trigger limit switches appropriately.

posts.name: Carter Eilert
posts.cooked: What’s the switch being used for? If it’s something like zeroing a mechanism, you could just flip a boolean if that mechanism would, in theory, trigger the switch. If it’s a way of detecting where coral is on the robot, there’s not really a good way to simulate that, but you could visualize it. In the simulation, the robot knows exactly where everything is, which means we can see if a limit switch is being triggered based on where the coral is.
If you have the simulation GUI open and click on Hardware > DIO, you should be able to adjust the values of digital inputs in your code.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: Here’s a screenshot of pigrammer’s comment. Don’t discount adding code to accept switches from SmartDashboard, ShuffleBoard, XBox controller buttons, etc., as that might be easier to control rapidly than using the Simulate GUI.

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked: You have to set the state of the simulated DIO manually. Let’s say you are trying to simulate a limit switch indicating an elevator is down. In a periodic method somewhere that makes sense for your code you need an if statement that checks if the simulated elevator height is within tolerance of the down position of the elevator and if it is set the simulated limit switch to the boolean state that indicates your elevator is down otherwise set it to the boolean state indicating not down. A similar concept applies to other types of mechanisms. If you have a pivoting arm and you want to simulate a limit switch which indicates the arm is in the stowed rotational position set up a check in a periodic method which compares the simulated arm angle to a reference angle and set your simulated limit switch value to the appropriate boolean state based on that comparison. I went out to GitHub and searched for simulation.DIOSim among the many hits I found an implementation of simulated limit switches on an elevator. This exact approach may not fit in to your code but the concept should help you understand the direction you need to go.

posts.name: Ephraim C.
posts.cooked: I was using the switch to test some LEDs on our robot today it worked perfectly. But wait, yesterday it didn't work at all. Also, the Wi-Fi signal was weak.

posts.name: Ephraim C.
